bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, December 20, 1928

div1.p: Carter writes about the final work that she and Brown are completing before Carter leaves for Baltimore and comments on the providence that connected her with someone as capable and dedicated as Brown.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, December 20, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 20, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I called up Baltimore, last night to see if I could find out
just what day Dr. Frost wanted me to go over to work with him.
From present indications it will not be until next week. In the
intermim. Miss Brown and I are selecting the material for my trip to
Baltimore (books that I think Frost had best see himself, Memoranda
etc. etc.) and also going over our bibliographic cards remaining, at this end
of the line, both complete and incomplete, so as to refresh my
memory on things I particularly wish to call to Dr. Frost's atten-
tion. Needless to say, there has been, and will be, no time taken
off for “Xmas shopping.” Miss Brown and I worked until late last
night and will probably work every night until I leave for Baltimore.
UnlessIt certainly was Providential that I “made connection” with such a
person as Miss Brown as soon as my share of the work reached a stage
where two people could handle it better than o[unclear]ne.

With heartfelt good wishes for a happy Christmas and the best
of New Years, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Mem. I also sent P. S. (by hand) of re
letters from (a) J. W. W. Stevens (b) [unclear]
School Trop. Med (c) Frederick Hoffman
